_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary-Geneva, NE. Terminal
I.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response 
Sunoco is committed to the safety of our employees, surrounding community, and the environment and the Geneva, NE. Terminal achieved OSHA VPP Star status on December 15, 2014, and recertified on December 11, 2017, and again on November 28, 2022. It is Sunocos policy to comply with all federal, state, and local laws as well as accepted industry practice for the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia, butane, propane and other liquefied petroleum gases. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the facility.

II.	Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances. The Geneva Terminal was built and put into service in 1953. The facility was built to store and transport propane (RMP regulated substance), refined products and a Liquid Mixture (LM) of the two products. The propane, refined products and the LM are delivered, via a 10 pipeline and a 16 pipeline, to the Geneva Terminal from the Sunoco Terminal in Concordia, Kansas. The 1,492,974 lbs. of propane, which exceeds the 10,000 lbs. threshold quantity (TQ) of the OSHA PSM requirements, is stored in, one of sixteen, pressurized bullet tanks. The LM is stored in two pressurized bullet tanks. The propane is removed from the site by either propane trucks that deliver it to various customers, or by one of four pipelines, which consist of two 8 pipelines and two 6 pipelines.

III.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps. The Sunoco Geneva, NE. Terminal will continue to address the RMP release prevention program with the following elements. 
	Training: Employees are trained in the safe handling of all products stored at the facility and are trained in appropriate emergency actions required tin response to a potentia

l release. Employee training includes participation in internal response drills with government agencies and local Fire Departments. Employees are trained and must demonstrate an understanding of the required task before being allowed to handle any RMP regulated substances. 
	Safety Equipment: Describe the safety system around the regulated substance. 
	Facility Design: The anhydrous ammonia, butane, propane handling facility has been designed to meet the standards set forth in NFPA 58 and is operated in compliance with the OSHA standard for the storage and handling of Liquefied Petroleum Gases (29 CFR 1910.110) 
IV.	Five-year Accident History 
The Sunoco Geneva, NE. Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. There has been no accidental release of a regulated substance, meeting the RMP five-year accident history reporting criteria, in the past five years. 
V.	Emergency Response Information
The Sunoco Geneva, NE. Terminal has developed and implemented a written emergency action plan to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The emergency response program is updated, when necessary, based on factors such as modifications made to the process or changes in the communication procedures. 
VI.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety 
The Sunoco Geneva, NE. Terminal will continue to improve employee training resources, conduct safety audits, and incident investigations, as applicable, to continuously improve worker and public safety. The terminal will also continue to actively manage changes to facilities, process chemistry, process technology, and process equipment, as well as to review and revise operating, maintenance, emergency, and communication procedures to ensure that they reflect current operating practices. Sunoco plans on holding emergency response drills/training exercises at the terminal.
